Award.AwardTitle: CRII: CIF: Measure Estimation from Moments: Theory, Algorithms, and Applications

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
From phase imaging in microscopy to semantic analysis of neural signals, scientific discovery relies on identifying models from massive noisy, incomplete, and corrupted data. One critical challenge for model identification is the nonlinearity inherent in most scientific models and data analysis tasks. However, as suggested by several successful approaches developed across machine learning, statistics, and optimization, nonlinear problems could become linear when "lifted" into higher dimensional spaces. Exploring the power and limitations of such "linearization" techniques plays an important role in complex model identification.

The research develops a unified framework of formulating nonlinear problems as infinite-dimensional linear problems using measure, a foundational concept of modern mathematics that abstracts the notion of volume and mass. In many measure estimation problems arising in physical and information sciences, the observations are linear functions of the measure's moments and the true measure describing the system is atomic with a small support. The work first delineates the class of model identification tasks that can be formulated as measure estimation from moments. Notable examples include tensor decomposition and completion, non-negative matrix factorization, and solving high-order multi-variate polynomial equations. Second, the project develops a unified theoretical and computational approach to solve measure estimation using semidefinite programming with guaranteed performance. Finally, the project provides efficient and scalable algorithms for applications in computational optics and large-scale data analysis, where the problems of measure estimation from moments arise frequently.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From phase imaging in microscopy to semantic analysis of neural signals, scientific discovery relies on identifying models from massive noisy, incomplete, and corrupted data. One critical challenge for model identification is the nonlinearity inherent in most scientific models and data analysis tasks. However, as suggested by several successful approaches developed across machine learning, statistics, control, and optimization, nonlinear problems could become linear when "lifted" into higher dimensional spaces. Exploring the power and limitations of such "linearization" techniques plays an important role in complex model identification.

The research developed a framework for formulating nonlinear problems as infinite-dimensional linear problems using the concept of measure. The project made progress in understanding the power and limitations of exploiting structural information using convex optimization, extending a line of work including compressive sensing, matrix completion, and recent developments in atomic norms. In particular, the research efforts showed that the same principle of enforcing parsimony can be used to solve tensor inverse problems, blind super-resolution, stable and robust spectral estimation, radar signal processing, and modal analysis. Concrete theoretical results were obtain to show that the proposed framework, when applied to aforementioned problems, yields estimators with minimax denoising performance, recovers signals from a minimal number of measurements, produces solutions that are robust to gross corruptions, and leads to support recovery with precisions approaching the Cramer-Rao lower bound. In sum, our results show that the developed measure estimation framework has the advantages of i) Grid-free: the approach avoids discretization and works with the continuous parameter space while still employing sparse regularization; ii) Modularity: the same principle can be applied to different settings without much change to the regularizer construction procedure; iii) Flexibility: noise, outliers, missing data, clutter, interference, etc. can be easily handled by regularizing the corresponding representing measures; iv) Optimality: the developed approach provides the best possible resolution (separation in targets) and precision (variance in target location estimation), and achieves minimax denoising performance and information theoretically optimal signal recovery; v) Computability: the resulting convex optimizations can be solved using off-the-shelf convex solvers or hand-crafted fast solvers using first-order methods. The convexity ensures freedom from convergence issues.

The project impacted the study of semidefinite relaxations for non-convex and sometimes NP-hard problems. Exact semidefinite reformulations were developed for problems involving trigonometric moments. For a subclass of tensor problems, it’s shown that relaxations of the lowest order are exact, in contrast to existing convergence results without explicit bound on the required relaxation order. By characterizing the class of nice instances that are solvable via semidefinite programming in polynomial time, the project also brought insight into the NP-hardness of many problems investigated in this project.

Finally, the project shed light on the connection between the convergence behavior of nonlinear programs and properties of their convex relaxations. By making connections between convex relaxations and the nonlinear reformulations, the research efforts show that for a large class of matrix optimizations, each critical point of the reformulated problem either corresponds to the optimal solution or is a strict saddle point where the Hessian matrix has a negative eigenvalue. Such a geometric structure of the reformulation ensures that many local search algorithms can converge to the global optimum with random initializations.

The project's efforts on outreach activities, course development, and student training are in line with the nation’s need of improving STEM education. The PI and the supported graduate students participated summer camps designed for underrepresented minority students and kids with learning disability, which contributed to the inspiration and attraction of more female and underrepresented minority students to choose STEM as a career option and increase the visibility and reputation of Colorado School of Mines in local community. The PI combined undergraduate teaching with outreach efforts. In his senior Digital Signal Processing class, the final projects required the students to develop K-12 outreach modules for the online digital library TeachingEngineering. Students worked in small teams, each picking a grade level in the K-12 range and thinking of an exercise–broadly related to signal processing–that is designed to intrigue and inspire students at that level. The PI created a new graduate course in convex optimization, attracting a wider audience of graduate students within the department and across campus. Optimization is a powerful tool that can be applied to solve problems in many engineering and science disciplines. To benefit the entire campus, the course emphasized the basic theory and algorithms of modern convex optimization, along with applications in various engineering and science fields.
